channel.title: Ars-Technica on Panz3r News
channel.description: Recent content in Ars-Technica on news.panz3r.dev

item.title: Biden shifts strategy as national vaccination rate continues to slow
item.description: Vaccinations have been steadily declining since mid-April.

item.title: NASA has selected its deep space hardware—now comes the fun part
item.description: “This isn’t a dream any more.”

item.title: Netflix IT exec forced employees to use products from vendors that bribed him
item.description: Jury finds ex-Netflix VP guilty of awarding tech contracts in exchange for bribes.

item.title: The new abnormal is warming up the US government’s new climate norms
item.description: The US’s expected weather are based on a 30-year average, updated once a decade.

item.title: Epic thinks EGS could make up 35-50% of the PC gaming market by 2024
item.description: Epic v. Apple gives us our deepest look yet into the economics of Epic’s storefront.

item.title: New Spectre attack once again sends Intel and AMD scrambling for a fix
item.description: A new transient execution variant is the first exploit micro-ops caches.

item.title: Today’s best deals: $40 Nintendo Switch games, Kindle Paperwhite, and more
item.description: Dealmaster also has deals on true wireless earbuds and Garmin running watches.

item.title: Frontier exits bankruptcy, claims it will double fiber-to-the-home footprint
item.description: Frontier plans 3 million new fiber lines—but 8M others would be stuck on copper.

item.title: Review: Shadow and Bone is a worthy adaptation of the Grishaverse novels
item.description: If Cursed had a love child with The X-Men—who was then raised by Doctor Zhivago.

item.title: Researchers raise bats in helium-rich air to check how they sense sound
item.description: Bats seem to have an innate sense of the speed of sound—and can’t adjust it.

item.title: Goodbye again, Flash—Microsoft makes removal from Windows 10 mandatory
item.description: Windows “Update for Removal of Adobe Flash Player” becomes mandatory this July.

item.title: How the next Patent Office director could shape the patent system
item.description: Obama created “death squads” for bad patents—Trump’s nominees curtailed them.

item.title: 4,700 Amazon employees had unauthorized access to private seller data
item.description: Shoddy security allowed various employees to use info to their advantage.

item.title: Stadia’s VP and head of product leaves Google
item.description: Google’s embattled Stadia division loses one of its highest-profile executives.

item.title: Starship flight attempt for Tuesday afternoon is scrubbed [Updated]
item.description: After four failures, SpaceX is really hoping to stick the landing this time.

item.title: Porsche and Penske: Two of racing’s most famous names join forces again
item.description: The pair will run teams in WEC and IMSA, and there will be customer cars, too.

item.title: The Martian’s Andy Weir is back to form with Project Hail Mary
item.description: Some quick and spoiler-free thoughts on the new book, out today.

item.title: FDA reportedly plans to authorize Pfizer’s COVID vaccine for teens 12-15 in days
item.description: Pfizer previously reported the vaccine was safe and effective in adolescents.

item.title: Epic vs. Apple opening arguments suggest a bitter battle over iOS’ future
item.description: Epic says it’s “suing for change.” Apple says Epic “just doesn’t want to pay.”

item.title: Yet another Google AI leader has defected to Apple
item.description: He will work under John Giannandrea, who also left Google for Apple.

item.title: Ajit Pai joins American Enterprise Institute and a firm that invests in ISPs
item.description: Post-FCC Pai will apparently keep pushing deregulation of broadband industry.

item.title: Apple reports 2 iOS 0-days that let hackers compromise fully patched devices
item.description: Webkit flaws in just-released iOS 14.5 lets attackers execute malicious code.

item.title: Technician for water co. linked to liver failure says his dog got liver illness
item.description: Technician said he only had a couple of hours of training and did what he was told.

item.title: EPA to eliminate climate “super pollutants” from refrigerators, air conditioners
item.description: Hydrofluorocarbons saved the ozone layer, but they’re killing the climate.

item.title: iFixit tears down Apple’s AirTag, finds a great spot for a keychain hole
item.description: Teardown shows Apple designed the AirTag around a big voice coil speaker.

item.title: Verizon agrees to sell Yahoo and AOL to private-equity firm for $5 billion
item.description: Apollo to buy Yahoo/AOL for $5B, didn’t have much competition from other bidders.

item.title: Epic vs. Apple trial starts today—here’s what to expect
item.description: Arguments will center on how to define a monopoly in the mobile app marketplace.

item.title: For lunar cargo delivery, NASA accepts risk in return for low prices
item.description: “You can’t go to the Moon on a fixed price for under $100 million."

item.title: Kroger will begin drone deliveries in Ohio this week
item.description: The FAA has finally started allowing commercial flights beyond the line of sight.

item.title: The Ars Technica Mother’s Day 2021 gift guide
item.description: Who needs flowers? We pick out a few gadgets to make Mom’s life more convenient.

item.title: Invincible S1: Clearly, TV’s most fun superhero shows are on Amazon these days
item.description: Not even Smallville could combine YA drama and superhero DNA this well.

item.title: Will Virgin Galactic ever be successful? A new book provides insights
item.description: “It’s hard to make decisions around here sometimes.”

item.title: Why are game-makers creating new Game Boy games in 2021?
item.description: New tools and wide-eyed nostalgia are driving a monochrome portable renaissance.

item.title: How one naughty bird cheats with fancy feather structures
item.description: Male tanager birds have more than one way to make their colors really pop for the ladies.

item.title: Four astronauts make first nighttime landing in the ocean since 1968
item.description: “I would just like to say, quite frankly, y’all are changing the world.”

item.title: White House says Vice President Kamala Harris will chair the Space Council
item.description: “I think her approach to this is just going to be to get the job done.”

item.title: What became of 2009’s Left 4 Dead 2 boycott? Here’s the inside story
item.description: In gaming since L4D2, fan campaigns have even pressured devs to release entirely new endings.

item.title: An ambitious plan to tackle ransomware faces long odds
item.description: Heavyweight task force proposes framework to tackle a major cybersecurity problem.

item.title: Ford’s ever-smarter robots are speeding up the assembly line
item.description: A transmission factory shows how AI may gradually creep into industrial processes

item.title: Disney gets special “theme park” exception to Florida’s anti-tech bill
item.description: A legal challenge to the new law seems inevitable.

item.title: More US agencies potentially hacked, this time with Pulse Secure exploits
item.description: Zero-day vulnerability under attack has a severity rating of 10 out of 10.

item.title: Mysterious health attacks like those seen in Cuba have come to DC
item.description: US security official was reportedly sickened outside the White House last year.

item.title: The NYPD retires “Digidog” robot after public backlash
item.description: Dystopian robot dogs will no longer be patrolling the mean streets of NYC.

item.title: New York requires $15 broadband for poor people, promptly gets sued by ISPs
item.description: Lobby groups for Verizon, AT�T, and other ISPs ask court to overturn state law.

item.title: Porsche rumored to be entering F1 with Red Bull Racing
item.description: Rumors of Porsche in F1 never go away, and a rival team boss thinks it’s happening.

item.title: Climate law jeopardizes freedoms, German court rules—but not how you think
item.description: Don’t punt on emissions reductions after 2030, top court said.

item.title: Roku vs. Google, part 2: YouTube TV app pulled from Roku Store
item.description: Google wants AV1 support for lower bandwidth costs, Roku says that’s too expensive.

item.title: Humble Bundle creator brings antitrust lawsuit against Valve over Steam
item.description: “At bottom, Valve’s scheme imposes a massive tax on the PC Desktop Gaming industry.”

item.title: New iPad Pro, Apple TV 4K, and 24-inch iMac now available for order
item.description: Most are shipping May 21, but the 12.9-inch iPad Pro has slipped several weeks.

item.title: EU says Apple’s 30% cut from rival music providers violates competition law
item.description: EU sides with Spotify, blasts Apple’s 30% App Store cut and anti-steering rules.

item.title: SpaceX cancels Starship flight attempt on Friday [Updated]
item.description: After four landing failures, here’s hoping the fifth time is the charm.

item.title: Dozens of viruses seem to use a different DNA base
item.description: Odd form of DNA helps viruses resist their host’s defenses.

item.title: What I learned about cars watching all 8 Fast & Furious movies in 4 days
item.description: Revisiting our 2019 marathon of vehicular wisdom, thanks to new theatrical promotion.

item.title: Rocket Report: Blue Origin protests Starship, China launches space station
item.description: “The ability to refuel in space is critical to meeting NASA’s goals."
